author: Divya Balji
title: Red-hot Canada stock rally comes to halt with reality sinking in
description: After seven dizzying weeks of gains, Canada’s stock market is at an impasse.
content:
After seven dizzying weeks of gains, Canada’s stock market is at an impasse. 
 Two back-to-back days of heavy losses this week was enough to snap the S&P/TSX Composite Index’s winning streak as health officials warned on premature reopenings, Wall Street heavyweights called for caution and trade tensions between the U.S. and China heightened. 
 Investors wagering on negative interest rates may be getting ahead of themselves as Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell and other central bankers dismissed going below zero. The Fed also issued a stark warning Friday, just as the market closed, that stock and other asset prices could suffer “significant declines” should the coronavirus pandemic deepen. 
 “We’ve effectively moved from the ‘shock and awe’ phase associated with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus to the ‘aw, shucks’ phase when investors recalibrate to the potential difficulties associated with containing and recovering from the global pandemic,” said Kurt Reiman, who sets strategy for the Canadian arm of BlackRock Inc. 
 
 Case in point: Asian economies that have seen some of the most success quelling the coronavirus are now facing resurgences. It’s a painful reminder that as countries open up again and people resume normal life, flare-ups are likely. Closer to home, Quebec had to push back the time frame to restart the economy in Montreal as the city and its suburbs became Canada’s biggest COVID-19 hotspot. In contrast, Ontario announced it would begin to reopen most stores, except for those in shopping malls. 
 The S&P/TSX Composite gained Friday, but was down 2.2 per cent for the week, trimming its gains to 30 per cent from the low on March 23. 
 “It’s normal to see a pullback in markets in any environment, especially given the highly uncertain backdrop created by he COVID-19 pandemic,” said Lesley Marks, chief investment officer at BMO Private Wealth. “Investors are realizing that even though there is optimism for a recovery with easing restrictions globally, the recovery will be slow and not necessarily be a smooth path upward.” 
 Reiman noted the uneven performance of various industries. Both growth and defensive sectors, like tech, utilities and consumer staples, had stronger earnings and returns in Canada and globally. Cyclicals like energy and financials experienced sharp earnings downgrades and dividend cuts. 
 Markets: Just The Numbers 
 Stocks 
• Financials, real estate and utility stocks led the declines on the TSX for the week, offset by tech and materials. 
 Bonds 
• The Canadian 10-year bond yield rose to 3.18 per cent, while two-year bond yields climbed 3.95 per cent. 
 Loonie 
• The Canadian dollar weakened by more than one per cent against the U.S. dollar this week. 
 Getting Defensive 
 While markets may have priced in the bad economic data released so far, there’s more to come. 
 “Our view is that in the coming months, we’re probably not going to see the same level of policy responses and announcements,” Craig Basinger, chief investment officer at Richardson GMP, said. “It’s hard to keep throwing a trillion dollars every month at the market. And at the same time, we’re going to start getting more bad more economic and earnings data.” 
 Basinger said he has reduced exposure to stocks in his funds and has tilted to a more defensive view. Second quarter-earnings results will be “anyone’s guess,” added Chris Kerlow, portfolio manager at Richardson GMP. 
 Blackrock’s Reiman prefers U.S. stocks for their greater exposure to companies with strong balance sheets and hefty U.S. fiscal and monetary-policy measures. He also prefers corporate bonds over stocks for higher and more stable income stream. 
 Chart of the Week 
 
 Economy 
 As far as the Bank of Canada is concerned, the country’s financial system remains resilient in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic and moves to keep credit markets functioning have been largely effective, though risks remain. The central bank’s balance sheet grew to $416.6 billion, about 18 per cent of Canada’s gross domestic product. 
 Consumer confidence is showing signs of improving as Canadians’ views on their personal finances, job security and expectations for the economy all improved. 
 Earlier this week, Justin Trudeau’s government unveiled a loan program for large companies with annual revenue of $300 million or more that have been hit by COVID-19 and can’t get financing by conventional means. Firms in all sectors can apply for the funding except the finance industry. 
 Politics 
 The world’s longest undefended border will likely remain shut until late June, according to a newspaper report. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said at a media briefing this week that Canada will be “very, very careful about reopening any international travel including the United States.”

title: The Daily Chase: TSX winning streak; market volatility boosts TMX profit
description: Noah Zivitz
content:
Noah Zivitz
                             
 Managing Editor, BNN Bloomberg   Follow | Archive 
 
 
 The S&P/TSX Composite Index matched its longest winning streak of the year yesterday, with its sixth straight day of gains. Once again, Shopify was the primary driver, adding 45 index points yesterday alone. Since the streak began, only two groups are under water: Materials and Health Care. We’ll continue probing the disconnect between the equity market’s rally and the economic devastation caused by the pandemic, including with Invesco Chief Global Market Strategist Kristina Hooper this morning at 9:30 a.m. ET. 
 AID FOR SENIORS 
 The federal government unveiled targeted aid for seniors this morning, including tax-free payments of $300 for those who are eligible for Old Age Security, and $200 for those who are eligible for the Guaranteed Income Supplement, at a total cost of $2.5 billion. Details  here. 
 IN CONVERSATION WITH TMX CEO 
 Market volatility was a profit boon for the TMX Group in the first quarter of the year. Adjusted earnings soared 19 per cent year-over-year as revenue rallied 12 per cent. The exchange owner/operator’s core equities and derivatives units were the primary beneficiaries of those breathtaking trading days as COVID-19 took hold. We’ll go in-depth on the quarter and outlook with interim CEO John McKenzie this morning. 
 CRISIS MANAGEMENT 
 RioCan CEO Ed Sonshine joins us this afternoon to share his perspective on the federal government’s decision to step up as the self-professed lender of last resort for Canada’s biggest companies with its Large Employer Emergency Financing Facility. And we’re also catching up today with two central figures in the feds’ plan to keep companies afloat: Business Development CEO Michael Denham and Export Development Canada CEO Mairead Lavery will join Jon Erlichman and Amanda Lang, respectively, to take us behind the scenes of liquidity crisis management. 
 OTHER NOTABLE STORIES 
 -Another frustrated  Teck Resources  investor is speaking out and calling for the miner to part ways with CEO Don Lindsay. “These have been poor investment decisions by this CEO, approved by mostly this board, and we’re expecting the same people who got us into this mess to get us out of this mess,” Impala Asset Management founder Bob Bishop told our Bloomberg partners. Bishop added that he believes Teck’s share price would go up 40 per cent in one day if the company “did the right thing.' 
 -We’ve heard the waste management industry is recession resistant. But what about lockdown resistant? In its first-quarter earnings release last night,  GFL Environmental  said its adjusted revenue fell 9.9% year-over-year in April as a result of “reduced commercial and industrial collection volume” that GFL pins on the impact of COVID-19. Overall, GFL’s quarterly revenue jumped 29% to $931.3 million. 
 - Tim Hortons  now has one of China’s dominant tech companies in its corner. Tencent is making an unspecified investment to support the coffee-and-doughnut chain’s expansion in the country. Separately, Restaurant Brands International CEO Jose Cil released an open letter this morning mapping out the company’s strategy for gradually resuming in-store dining at the fast-food conglomerate’s chains.   
 -Despite seeing its profit sink 25 per cent plunge in the first quarter, Saudi Aramco has  reaffirmed  its capital spending budget for the year and said it will pay US$18.75 billion in dividends for the quarter. 
 -Tesla CEO Elon Musk  invited law enforcement to arrest him  in a Twitter post yesterday announcing the vehicle maker would defy local rules and resume production at its California plant. 
 - Tilray  shares are slipping in pre-market trading after the B.C.-based cannabis producer reported wider first-quarter losses (net and on EBITDA basis). Revenue more than doubled compared to the year-ago period. 
 - BlackRock  will be a stock to watch after the world's largest asset manager said PNC Financial is planning to exit its position as BlackRock's top shareholder. PNC shares are up more that six per cent in pre-market trading.

title: The Daily Chase: Feds unveil aid for large companies; TSX looks to extend winning streak
description: Noah Zivitz
content:
Noah Zivitz
                             
 Managing Editor, BNN Bloomberg   Follow | Archive 
 
 
 The federal government has unveiled its aid plan for Canada's largest companies. In a press release this morning, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced the establishment of a Large Employer Emergency Financing Facility (LEEFF). It's a financing mechanism for companies that need the additional support to "keep their operations going." Any company wanting to tap the program will have to file annual climate reports and adhere to "strict limits to dividends, share buybacks, and executive pay." Which raises important questions about who will sign up. 
 TSX WINNING STREAK 
 The composite index enters this week riding a five-session winning streak. Those gains in every day last week only added up to a 2.37 per cent uptick for the TSX, which has now climbed 33 per cent off the COVID-era low set on March 23. The info tech group led the way last week (and that wasn’t just a Shopify story), while Air Canada was the TSX’s lead laggard. 
 MINING M&A 
 We’ve got another at-market deal in the mining sector. SSR Mining has struck a friendly agreement to buy Alacer Gold in an all-stock deal that matches Alacer’s closing price of $8.19/share Friday. It’s being billed as a merger of equals notwithstanding the fact SSR shareholders will emerge with 57 per cent of the combined entity, which will be based in SSR’s home base of Colorado. Meanwhile, Barrick Gold CEO Mark Bristow told The Financial Times he’s eyeing opportunities to expand the miner’s copper business; adding, with regard to speculation about Freeport-McMoRan, “there are no options off the table.” 
 CRUDE FUTURES BOUNCE 
 The price of oil made a dramatic intraday move at 8 a.m. ET today, swinging seven per cent after our Bloomberg partners moved a story about Saudi Arabia making a “voluntary and unilateral” production cut of 1 million barrels per day. A spokesperson for the Saudi energy ministry is quoted as saying the kingdom is aiming “to encourage OPEC+ participants, as well as other producing countries, to comply” with output cuts that were recently agreed upon 
 OTHER NOTABLE STORIES 
 -Elon Musk announced on Twitter Saturday Tesla will move its HQ to “Texas/Nevada immediately” after the vehicle maker sued California’s Alameda County over preventing Tesla’s plant from resuming operations. 
 -Ontario’s Financial Accountability Office this morning said the province faces a record $41-billion budget deficit this year with COVID-19 poised to “deliver a severe blow” to revenue and push spending higher. 
 -Cameco says it’s planning to restart operations next week at its Port Hope conversion facility and Blind River refinery. Both were put into shutdown mode in early April as a result of COVID-related restrictions. 
 -Macy's could be a stock to watch today after Vesa Equity Investments disclosed a five per cent stake in the department store chain, and said it will seek "constructive discussions" with some mix of Macy's management, its board, and other stakeholders. 
 -U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson yesterday delivered his “conditional plan” to loosen his country’s lockdown rules, starting by saying those who can’t work from home “should be actively encouraged” to resume their work, while candidly stating “this is not the time simply to end the lockdown this week.”

title: North American equities pare gains, Nasdaq holds gains for 2020
description: 4:25 p.m. ET: North American equities pare gains, Nasdaq holds gains for 2020
content:
4:25 p.m. ET: North American equities pare gains, Nasdaq holds gains for 2020 
 North American equity markets pared gains into the closing bells, finishing near session lows. The S&P/TSX Composite Index was essentially unchanged, up 0.02 per cent, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was 0.89 per cent higher, the S&P 500 gained 1.15 per cent and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 1.41 per cent. 
 The Nasdaq’s advances had the tech-heavy composite back in positive territory for the year, although it was still down more than eight per cent from February’s record highs. 
 In Toronto, five of the eleven TSX subgroups were in positive territory, led by consumer discretionary, materials and energy stocks. Health care, utilities and financials were the largest percentage decliners. 
 Crude prices failed to hang on to gains made earlier in the day, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate shedding 2.4 per cent to trade around US$23.50 per barrel. The declines came after oil gained as much as 11 per cent in early Thursday trading following optimism surrounding Saudi Arabia’s actions to support the crude market. Canada’s Western Canadian Select fell nearly 10 per cent to trade at US$17.44 per barrel, though Canadian crude is priced sporadically throughout the day. 
 The Canadian dollar pushed higher against its U.S. counterpart, rising eight tenths of a cent to 71.48 cents U.S. 
 1:15 p.m. ET: North American markets hold on to gains, Nasdaq positive for 2020 
 North American equity markets held on to their gains into the early afternoon, with the S&P/TSX Composite Index up a little less than half a per cent, the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average both notching 1.6 per cent gains and the Nasdaq Composite turning in the strongest performance, up 1.81 per cent. 
 The Nasdaq’s continued gains have pushed the tech-heavy composite into positive territory year-to-date, though it remains about eight per cent below its Feb. 19 high. A slate of tech titans viewed as being well-positioned to capitalize on the work-from-home, self-isolation orders have helped lift the index. 
 In Toronto, six of the eleven TSX subgroups were in positive territory, with energy, consumer discretionary and materials stocks posting the largest percentage gains. On the flip side, health care, information technology and utilities were posting the largest percentage declines. 
 On a stock-specific basis, Primo Water Corp. – formerly known as Cott Beverage – was the lead gainer on the TSX Composite, up 10 per cent after posting an 11 per cent jump in revenue in its fiscal first quarter. Bombardier Inc. was the worst performing stock on the index, falling 10 per cent after reporting negative free cash flow of US$1.6-billion in its most recent quarter as the global aerospace industry strains under the weight of the COVID-19 virus. 
 In all, 136 of the 230 TSX components were in positive territory. 
 Crude oil pared earlier gains, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate up about four per cent to trade just shy of US$25 per barrel. Oil had been buoyed by optimism surrounding Saudi Arabia’s decision to boost prices to bring further stability to global oil markets battered by the virus outbreak and subsequent economic shutdowns. 
 Canadian crude was essentially unchanged into the early afternoon, with Western Canadian Select trading at US$19.46 per barrel. 
 The Canadian dollar was up eight-tenths of a cent against its American counterpart to trade at 71.50 cents U.S., though the greenback was broadly weaker against its global peers. 
 9:40 a.m. ET: North American equity markets rise, Nasdaq erases 2020 losses 
 North American equity markets rose in early trading Thursday, with the S&P/TSX Composite Index up 0.9 per cent, the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.1 per cent and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 1.3 per cent apiece. 
 The tech-heavy Nasdaq has erased its year-to-date losses as some of the tech titans gain, though the composite is still about 8.5 per cent below its February 19 peak. 
 The push higher across the major indices comes as investors filter through a deluge of earnings and historically ugly economic data. 
 Oil prices surged, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate up nine per cent to trade at US$26.25 per barrel. Crude rose amid signs Saudi Arabia is raising prices in a bid to shore up the beleaguered oil market, which is facing unprecedented demand destruction due to the global economic clampdown to slow the COVID-19 virus outbreak. 
 Alberta’s Western Canadian Select rose 12 per cent to trade at US$21.76 per barrel. 
 The Canadian dollar gained about four-tenths of a cent against its U.S. counterpart to 71.05 cents U.S.

author: Ian Vandaelle
title: TSX lifted by Shopify; Wall Street mixed to close choppy trading day
description: 4:30 p.m. ET: North American markets closed mixed after choppy trading session
content:
4:30 p.m. ET: North American markets closed mixed after choppy trading session 
 North American markets were mixed to close out a choppy Wednesday trading session, with the S&P/TSX Composite Index rising 0.13 per cent, the Nasdaq Composite up 0.51 per cent, the S&P 500 down 0.70 per cent and the Dow Jones Industrial Average shedding 0.91 per cent. 
 In Toronto, seven of the 11 TSX subgroups closed the day in positive territory. The information technology, industrials and financials subindices posted the largest percentage gains for the day. 
 Shopify Inc. was at the forefront of the rally, with the ecommerce darling alone adding 50 points to the overall composite. The company’s post-earnings rally pushed its market capitalization into rarified territory, with its valuation eclipsing that of Royal Bank of Canada and becoming the nation’s most valuable firm. Shopify posted a 47 per cent jump in revenue in its most recent quarter and the company’s shares have been on a tear, nearly doubling so far this year. 
 Meanwhile, materials, energy and utilities were the largest decliners. Shares of Barrick Gold Corp. dragged on the materials subgroup after the mining giant was forced to trim its production forecast due to a dispute with Papua New Guinea. The country is looking to secure a greater profit share of Barrick's Porgera mine, prompting the government to deny the gold giant and its partner, China’s Zijin Mining, the right to continue operations. 
 Oil prices slid, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate down two per cent to trade at US$24.04 per barrel. Canadian crude also fell, with Western Canadian Select prices down 2.22 per cent to US$19.35 per barrel. 
 The Canadian dollar shed nearly half a cent against its U.S. counterpart to trade at 70.75 cents U.S. 
 1:00 p.m. ET: Markets mixed in choppy trade, Shopify threatens to dethrone RBC 
 North American equity markets were mixed in a choppy Wednesday trade, with the S&P/TSX Composite Index about 0.2 per cent higher, the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average essentially unchanged and the Nasdaq Composite Index rising a little more than one per cent. 
 In Toronto, seven of the 11 TSX subgroups were in positive territory, with information technology, communications and consumer staples posting the biggest percentage gains. 
 Info tech was driven by a jump in shares of Shopify Inc., which gained after the company posted a 47 per cent increase in revenue, year-over year. The ecommerce platform provider now boasts a market capitalization of almost $120-billion, putting it within striking distance of Royal Bank of Canada for the title of the largest publicly-listed company in Canada. 
 It’s rare for any non-financial stock to become the most valuable company on the TSX, with BlackBerry and Nortel Networks being the only tech companies to attain the feat. 
 Oil prices continued to slide, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate down about 4.7 per cent, threatening to snap a five-session winning streak. Alberta’s Western Canadian Select was down six per cent to trade at US$18.48 per barrel. 
 9:40 a.m. ET: North American equity markets post modest gains at the open 
 North American equity markets were modestly higher in early Wednesday trading.  
 The S&P/TSX Composite Index rose 0.6 per cent, the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average were up about half a per cent and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.8 per cent. Those major North American indices are now on track for three straight sessions of gains as investors assess the potential for global economic reopening plans in the face of the COVID-19 outbreak. 
 Oil prices were under  pressure, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate prices shedding five per cent of their value to trade at US$23.25 per barrel. WTI has recovered from its lows, but prices are still down about 60 per cent year-to-date. 
 Canadian crude was down about seven per cent to trade at US$18.42 per barrel. 
 The Canadian dollar fell a quarter of a cent against its U.S. counterpart to trade at 70.94 cents U.S.

author: Ian Vandaelle
title: North American equity markets pare gains into the close
description: 4:20 p.m. ET: North American equity markets pare gains into the close
content:
4:20 p.m. ET: North American equity markets pare gains into the close 
 North American equity markets pared their gains, into the close but held on to positive territory to extend gains into a second day. The S&P/TSX Composite Index rose 0.45 per cent, the S&P 500 notched a 0.90 per cent gain, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.56 per cent the Nasdaq Composite Index posted a 1.13 per cent gain. 
 Oil prices continued to surge, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate up 20.3 per cent shortly after 4 p.m. ET to hold at US$24.50 per barrel. Crude has gained in each of the last five trading sessions amid optimism over OPEC+ supply cuts coming online as the cartel and its partners look to combat the global demand destruction wrought by the COVID-19 pandemic. 
 Canadian crude also gained, with Alberta’s Western Canadian Select up 20.9 per cent to trade just shy of US$20 per barrel. 
 In Toronto, information technology, utilities and materials led the way higher, with eight of the 11 TSX subgroups in positive territory. Only financials, consumer discretionary and consumer staples stocks closed the session lower. 
 On a stock-specific basis, MEG Energy Corp., which is highly levered to the price of oil, was the top gainer on the composite, up 16 per cent. Westshore Terminals Investment Corp. and Sleep Country Canada Holdings rounded out the top three. 
 The Canadian dollar was modestly higher against its American counterpart, rising two-tenths of a cent to trade at 71.20 cents U.S. 
 12:45 p.m. ET: North American equity markets maintain momentum through midday 
 North American equity markets continued to trade in positive territory through midday, with the S&P/TSX Composite Index rising 0.6 per cent, the S&P 500 up 1.7 per cent, the Dow Jones Industrial Average pushing 1.4 per cent higher and the Nasdaq Composite Index up nearly two per cent. 
 In Toronto, eight of the 11 TSX subgroups were in the green, led by information technology, energy and real estate. Materials were the weakest sector on the composite. 
 Oil continued to gain ground, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate up 21 per cent to trade close to US$25 per barrel. Canadian crude also gained, with Western Canadian Select up 17 per cent to trade at US$19.16 per barrel. 
 9:40 a.m. ET: North American equities extend rally, crude prices surge 
 North American equity markets rallied at the open of trading Tuesday, with the S&P/TSX Composite Index up a little more than one per cent and the S&P 500, Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index all up more than one-and-a-quarter per cent. 
 The positive showing extended the rally for the major North American indices to four days, as investors assess the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak and the early steps to reopen regional economies. 
 Oil headed for its longest string of daily gains in nine months, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate up 15 per cent to trade at US$23.45 per barrel. WTI has traded higher in each of the last five sessions. Crude has gotten a boost amid optimism the OPEC+ production curtailments that came into effect at the beginning of the month could help combat the global oversupply in the face of declining demand due to the virus outbreak. 
 Alberta’s Western Canadian Select was up 18 per cent to trade at US$19.33 per barrel. 
 The Canadian dollar was up a third of a cent against its U.S. counterpart to trade at 71.35 cents U.S.

title: North American equities snap two-day losing streak
description: 4:30 p.m. ET
content:
4:30 p.m. ET 
 North American equity markets snapped a two-session slide on Monday, turning in their first positive sessions for the first time since last Wednesday. The &P/TSX Composite Index rose 0.85 per cent, the S&P 500 gained 0.42 per cent, the Dow Jones Industrial Average ticked 0.11 per cent higher and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index was up 1.23 per cent. 
 In Toronto, eight of the 11 TSX subgroups finished in positive territory, with information technology, materials and energy posting the largest percentage gains. The real estate sector notched the largest decline, falling 1.45 per cent. 
 On a stock-specific level, the breadth of the rally was modest, with 119 of the TSX’s 230 constituents finishing in positive territory. Shopify Inc. continued its march higher, with the tech darling gaining 7.63 per cent to add nearly 50 points to the composite. 
 Oil prices were higher after some early pressure, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate up 7.8 per cent to trade at US$21.33 per barrel shortly after 4 p.m. ET. Crude has been buffeted by concerns of overproduction and supply destruction amid the COVID-19 outbreak, along with some technical issues around when contracts for physical delivery come due. The OPEC+ production curtailments to address the former issue came into effect last Friday. 
 Canadian crude also saw gains, with Western Canadian Select rising 17 per cent to US$16.37 per barrel, though it’s only priced a handful of times per day. 
 11:40 a.m. ET 
 North American equity markets bounced off their lows in midday trading Monday. The S&P/TSX Composite Index was down about 0.1 per cent, the S&P 500 was about 0.2 per cent lower, the Dow Jones Industrial Average shed about 0.75 per cent of its value and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index pushed into positive territory, up about 0.5 per cent. 
 In Toronto, seven of the eleven TSX subgroups were in negative territory, with real estate, consumer staples and industrials posting the largest percentage declines. Information technology, materials and energy were the lead gainers on the index. 
 Oil prices fluctuated, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate down about one per cent after earlier breaking into positive territory. Alberta’s Western Canadian Select held its ground to trade at US$15.06 per barrel. 
 9:35 a.m. ET 
 North American equity markets extended last week's slide into the open of Monday’s trade. The S&P/TSX Composite Index fell 0.7 per cent, the S&P 500 down more than three-quarters of one per cent, the Dow Jones Industrial Average shed a full per cent and the Nasdaq Composite Index lost half a per cent. 
 The major North American indices are down in each of the last three sessions as investors navigate the COVID-19 crisis and the potential economic impact of reopening some regions. 
 Oil snapped a three-session string of gains, with the U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling two per cent to US$19.38 per barrel. Crude has been volatile due to a combination of the demand destruction wrought by the virus and some technical trading concerns over the expiration of monthly contracts.

title: The Daily Chase: TSX looks to extend gains; Rosenberg sees depression
description: Noah Zivitz
content:
Noah Zivitz
                             
 Managing Editor, BNN Bloomberg   Follow | Archive 
 
 
 Don’t look now, but the S&P/TSX Composite Index has recovered half the losses it suffered since COVID-19 and crashing oil prices sparked global market turmoil. From the Feb. 20 all-time closing high to the trough on March 23, the TSX shed 6715.6 points. By yesterday’s close, the TSX had recovered 3,413.6 of those points. Only four stocks (Pason Systems, Bombardier, Enerflex, Hexo) have failed to participate in that rally off the low. Is the move justified? And what’s an investor to do now? We’ll ask investment professionals.   
 ROSENBERG CALLS DEPRESSION 
 “It is a global depression.” Those were the words of economist David Rosenberg when asked by Amanda Lang if what we’re witnessing is the d-word. He pointed to “potentially a 40 per cent plunge in GDP with no recovery in sight” and said he believes this downturn could be 10 times worse that the 2008-09 collapse. His statements make the TSX’s aforementioned rally all the more curious. And Rosenberg’s commentary stands in stark contrast to what Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz told CTV News Chief News Anchor Lisa LaFlamme a couple weeks ago, when he said comparisons to the Great Depression are “misleading” and “inappropriate”. We have a poll on this at BNNBloomberg.ca so you can have your say. 
 TENSION BUILDS AS RENT LOOMS 
 With another round of rent payments coming due on Friday, tension is mounting even as the federal government attempts to engineer some relief. The key to that relief program for commercial tenants is held by landlords. So what happens if they choose to not avail themselves of the feds’ forgivable loan program? We need to keep hearing from voices on both sides of the equation. Today, we’ll check in with Dan Kelly from the Canadian Federation of Independent Business. 
 OTHER NOTABLE STORIES 
 -More wild swings in the price of oil: after plunging as much as 21 per cent this morning, last time I checked the June West Texas Intermediate futures contract was down seven per cent 
 -CN Rail managed to boost its adjusted first-quarter profit four per cent and improve its operating ratio in a period that saw the nation gripped by a rail blockade crisis (and, go figure, its petroleum and chemicals shipments were the primary revenue growth driver). Today's crisis of COVID-19 is forcing CN to yank its forecasts, while saying it's committed to its current dividend rate and it's "still working" to generate at least $2.5 billion of free cash flow.  We’ll speak with CEO Jean-Jacques Ruest this afternoon. 
 -The perils of forecasting are evident this morning as earnings season ramps up in the U.S.:  PepsiCo ,  UPS,  and  3M  pulled their outlooks (the latter while reporting a 21 per cent spike in first-quarter health care sales); Southwest Airlines said it’s “unable to reasonably estimate trends beyond May” (also said it’s pulling the 737 Max from its schedule through end of October);  Merck  cut its full-year sales and profit forecast ranges; and there’s not outlook from  Caterpillar , which reported double-digit first-quarter revenue declines in all of its industrial segments. One outlier:  Pfizer  reaffirmed its full-year revenue and profit outlooks. Its shares are up more than two per cent pre-market. 
 - Calfrac Well Services  announced this morning it’s slashing 70 per cent of its North American workforce in response to ongoing deterioration in market conditions.  
 - HSBC Bank Canada  says its first-quarter pre-tax profit plunged 66 per cent as it took a $140-million charge tied to anticipated credit losses. 
 -BP  kicked off earnings season for the global energy supermajors this morning with adjusted first-quarter profit shrinking to US$791 million from US$2.36 billion a year earlier. The company acknowledged there’s “severe pressure on storage and logistics” and, in a nod to COVID-19, said it’s facing demand destruction for its Downstream operations. Despite that, it’s holding its quarterly dividend.

title: The Daily Chase: Oil's historic plunge; Kenney's warning
description: Noah Zivitz
content:
Noah Zivitz
                             
 Managing Editor, BNN Bloomberg   Follow | Archive 
 
 
 After yesterday’s historic slide into negative prices, the WTI crude contract for May delivery has spent some time in positive territory this morning ahead of its expiry. The far more heavily-traded June contract has been down more than 40 per cent in early trading amid the great unknown of when COVID-related lockdowns will end. “You need demand to come back,” energy economist Jan Stuart told us yesterday afternoon. “You tell me when the public schools will open in California, or New York, or Toronto, and I’ll tell you when demand picks up.” We’ll continue chasing industry and investor insight on the Canadian energy sector’s coping strategy and the implications for the economy, and we look forward to speaking with Natural Resources Minister Seamus O’Regan this afternoon. 
 Notable sidebars on topic of easing the lockdown:  The governor of Georgia is loosening his state’s rules this Friday in what could be a case study for other North American jurisdictions. The state is reporting more than 19,000 confirmed cases and 774 deaths as of this morning. Meanwhile, U.S. President Trump used exclamation marks in  his tweet  announcing immigration into his country is being suspended:  
 KENNEY WARNS 
 On the subject of economic fallout, Alberta Premier Jason Kenney warned late yesterday that hundreds of thousands of jobs “are on the line” and that a wide swath of stakeholders “could all be jeopardized” as a result. He said there are ongoing conversations underway with the Texas Railroad Commission and U.S. Department of Energy about the potential for coordinated action in North America to address the storage and pricing problem, while acknowledging “at this point, really, it’s going to be market forces …that inevitably force further shut ins.” 
 TSX DEFIES OIL CRASH 
 For all the attention focused on crashing oil prices yesterday, the S&P/TSX Composite was the only major North American index to close with a gain. Credit goes to  Shopify , which tacked 41 points onto the index as it rose for an eighth straight session – over which time it has soared 67.3 per cent (and it was adding to those gains after opening higher this morning). Its surge seems to have happened faster than analysts can calibrate their expectations: 15 of 32 tracked by Bloomberg have a Buy recommendation, while only one (Mark Mahaney at RCB Capital Markets) has a price target above yesterday’s closing price.                        
 TECK BOOKS HALF-BILLION FORT HILLS IMPAIRMENT 
 Teck Resources swung to a loss in the first quarter due to a $474-million after-tax impairment on its ownership stake in the massive Fort Hills oil sands mine. And after CEO Don Lindsay stirred up a frenzy a few weeks ago when he said the ownership group had looked at the possibility of taking the project offline due to weak prices, the miner still isn’t ruling anything out. “The Fort Hills Partners continue to monitor market conditions and may adjust the operating plan of Fort Hills accordingly,” Teck said in its quarterly report. Overall, the company’s adjusted profit was in line with expectations, albeit down sharply from last year.   
 OTHER NOTABLE STORIES 
 -Air Canada said it will suspend all scheduled service to the United States after April 26 as a result of Canada and the United States’ recent decision to keep border restrictions in place for another 30 days. The airline plans to resume service on May 22.   
 -Back to oil crash fallout for a moment: Horizons ETFs Management announced today it is halting new subscription for its 2x bull and bear oil products on the TSX (HOU and HOD), while noting it’s still accepting redemption requests. In its release, Horizons said it “strongly discourages investors from purchasing” the ETFs for the time being because they’re likely to trade at “substantial premiums” to NAV so long as the subscription suspension is in place. 
 -Energy services firm Shawcor today said it will likely take an impairment charge of up to $250 million as a result of the industry’s challenges. Also says 7.5 per cent of its workforce has been laid off. 
 -Linamar withdrew its forecasts late yesterday and said COVID-19 will have a “significant impact” on its financial performance this year. Also said it’s stress testing its balance sheet and that its financial models still indicate it can be profitable this year.  
 -AutoCanada is suspending its dividend and says it has negotiated “headroom” on its senior credit facility. It also said 40% of its workforce has been laid off.

title: Shopify leapfrogs Brookfield to become No. 3 stock in Canada
description: A furious rally in Shopify Inc. has vaulted the e-commerce retailer to the third-largest company in Canada -- underscoring the value of the virtual world in the time of the coronavirus.
content:
A furious rally in Shopify Inc. has vaulted the e-commerce retailer to the third-largest company in Canada -- underscoring the value of the virtual world in the time of the coronavirus. 
 Shopify soared as much as 10 per cent to a record on Friday after its Chief Technology Officer Jean-Michel Lemieux said in a tweet that the Ottawa-based company was handling “Black Friday level traffic every day!” as it brings “thousands” of businesses online. 
 The move extended a seven-day surge to almost 50 per cent, giving it a market value of about $92 billion. That put Shopify, which provides tools for companies to sell over the internet, behind only Royal Bank of Canada and Toronto-Dominion Bank as the biggest companies in Canada’s stock market. 
 Investors now see more value in Shopify than Canadian companies that have been around for decades: Brookfield Asset Management Inc. with its billions of dollars worth of real estate, infrastructure and renewable power across the world, as well as pipeline giant Enbridge Inc., Canadian National Railway Co. and Bank of Nova Scotia. 
 With more consumers shifting online, Shopify is getting a leg up while the value of retail malls and office towers are being questioned, even in a post-viral world.

author: Claire Ballentine
title: ETF investors are all-in on stimulus with US$17 billion stock bet
description: As stocks posted their biggest weekly gain since 1974, skeptical Wall Street veterans shook their heads in amazement. But exchange-traded fund investors did what they always do -- they piled in.
content:
As stocks posted their biggest weekly gain since 1974, skeptical Wall Street veterans shook their heads in amazement. But exchange-traded fund investors did what they always do -- they piled in. 
 In only seven trading days this month, equity ETFs took in more than US$16.5 billion, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The torrid pace puts inflows on track to exceed the monthly total of US$42.5 billion in December, when stocks rallied during what ended up being the tail end of an 11-year bull market. 
 The surge in stocks last week, when U.S. shares gained a combined US$3.2 trillion, represents a bounce after the S&P 500 Index cratered 30 per cent in March. Optimists -- including mom-and-pop investors who use ETFs -- are focusing on massive fiscal and monetary stimulus meant to offset the impact of the pandemic, even as analysts predict one of the biggest economic contracts in U.S. history and the worst earnings season ever seen. 
 One explanation is that investors are already looking past the next two quarters after the S&P 500’s rapid decline of more than 30 per cent in March, and are now focusing on the recovery and the economic support supplied by the massive fiscal and monetary stimulus measures. It’s a narrative that ETF investors, especially retail ones, have followed for duration of the sell-off. 
 “We saw a lot of emotional selling at the beginning of the outbreak, and it was mostly in very liquid vehicles,” said Chad Oviatt, director of investment management at Huntington Private Bank. “When you go back to risk on, you will start to see more flows into equity vehicles whether that’s ETFs or mutual funds.” 
 ETFs used by allocators, which are typically longer-term retail investors and advisers, added US$41.1 billion in the first quarter, while those favored by professional traders lost almost US$27 billion. Vanguard equity fund flows, popular with mom and pop, are up almost 6 per cent year-to-date. 
 
 
A big contributor is the health care sector, which leads equity ETF flows with almost US$3 billion added, as drugmakers race to find a cure for the new coronavirus and companies rush equipment to hospitals. 
 State Street’s Health Care Select Sector SPDR Fund, ticker XLV, posted a record inflow of almost US$1.9 billion on Wednesday, while BlackRock’s iShares U.S. Medical Devices ETF, ticker IHI, saw its biggest one-day inflow on record Thursday, adding US$578 million. 
 Still, a worse-than-expected earnings season or more negative news on the virus spread could quickly reverse the inflows. Bank of America Corp. analysts said it would be unparalleled if the stock market fails to retest lows. 
 “A lot of investors are looking at these moves and saying, are we going to test the lows?” said Lance McGray, head of ETFs at Advisors Asset Management. “If we do make a move lower, I think you could see some potential outflows. The next week or two are going to provide some color in terms of where we go.”

 9:35 a.m. ET: North American markets post modest gains at the open

title: March trading volume on TSX more than doubled compared with a year ago
description: TORONTO - The number of shares traded on Canada's main stock exchange in March more than doubled compared with a year ago as the stock market plunged due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
content:
TORONTO - The number of shares traded on Canada's main stock exchange in March more than doubled compared with a year ago as the stock market plunged due to the COVID-19 pandemic. 
 According to statistics released by TMX Group Ltd., which operates the exchange, the volume of stocks traded on the Toronto Stock Exchange reached nearly 16.8 billion, up from 8.3 billion in March 2019. 
 The number of transactions for the month totalled 50.8 million, up from nearly 20.7 million in the same month last year. 
 The volume of shares traded on the Toronto Stock Exchange for the first three months of the year was up 35.5 per cent compared with 2019, while the number of transactions was up 49 per cent. 
 The S&P/TSX composite plunged last month as steps taken to slow the spread of COVID-19 forced the closure of non-essential businesses and the price of oil fell as Saudi Arabia and Russia started a price war. 
 TMX Group says the volume of trading on all its equity marketplaces, which includes the Toronto Stock Exchange, TSX Venture Exchange, TSX Alpha Exchange and Montreal Exchange, in March was up more than 70 per cent compared with March 2019.

5:20 p.m. ET Market Wrap: North American markets rally after weak start to second quarter 
 North American equity markets ended the day solidly in positive territory after a rough start to the second quarter. The S&P/TSX composite index rose 1.72 per cent Thursday, lifted by rising oil prices, while the S&P 500, Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite shrugged off earlier losses to post gains of between 1.7 and 2.3 per cent to finish near session highs.

Alberta’s Western Canadian Select surged 66 per cent, though it remains in the eight-dollar per barrel range. 
 That jump in crude price helped lift the Canadian dollar, which rose to 70.72 cents U.S. at 4:45 p.m. ET after flirting with the sub-70 cents level earlier in the day.

 Teck Resources Ltd. suspended its full-year guidance and announced it has put construction activity at its QB2 project in Chile on hold, with no certainty on the timeline to resume construction. Shares fell more than seven per cent at the open of trading on Wednesday.

author: Ian Vandaelle
title: 'Soul-sucking experience': Energy batters TSX in 2020's first quarter
description: Well, it could have been worse.
content:
Well, it could have been worse. 
 But that’s of cold comfort to Canadian equity investors. The S&P/TSX Composite Index capped off the first quarter down 21.59 per cent, the 41st best performer among 88 global stock exchanges tracked by Bloomberg. Every single one of them ended the quarter in the red as the world economy began to grind to a halt in the face of the COVID-19 outbreak, reflecting the flight to safety that took stocks out at the knees. Botswana came the closest to positive territory, sliding only 0.09 per cent, while Argentina’s Merval Index plummeted nearly 42 per cent. 
 None of the TSX subsectors finished the quarter in positive territory, with a one-two punch of the pandemic and fallout from the oil-price war hammering Canada’s benchmark index. Even the materials sector failed to get a bid, in spite of gold’s status as a safe-haven play in times of uncertainty. Below, BNN Bloomberg takes stock of the quarter that was. 
 Losers: 
 Energy:  -38.2 per cent 
 Health Care:  -37.3 per cent 
 Consumer Discretionary:  - 33.3 per cent 
 Energy stocks were sent to the mat as the COVID-19 crisis and the price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia battered sentiment around energy. Global oil demand is widely expected to fall by 15 to 20 million barrels a day as those twin headwinds take their toll. West Texas Intermediate crude booked its worst quarter on record, and Western Canadian Select prices fell below US$5 per barrel to hit a new all-time low. 
 Ninepoint Partners senior portfolio manager Eric Nuttall said the first quarter of 2020 will go down in the record books. In an email to BNN Bloomberg, Nuttall said the devastation in the energy industry is unlikely to be forgotten any time soon. 
 “The first quarter for energy investors was by any measure an agonizing, soul-sucking experience that saw oil fall by over 60 per cent and industry stalwarts such as Suncor Energy Inc. and Cenovus Energy Inc. fall by as much as 20 per cent to 50 per cent in a single day. There was nowhere to hide,” he said. “With oil falling to levels that are forcing shut-ins, we await global oil demand to recover as COVID-19’s devastating economic impact lessens. One thing is clear: the oil abundance of today will lead to an oil supply crisis in the years ahead.” 
 Health Care, now dominated by the volatile cannabis stocks, was almost equally damaged. Aurora Cannabis Inc. and Hexo Corp. were the biggest losers, with the former seeing its share price cut in half and the latter losing almost 45 per cent of its value. 
 Purpose Investments chief investment officer Greg Taylor, who manages the firm’s Marijuana Opportunities Fund, said he anticipates the crisis will quickly separate the winners and losers in the sector. In an email to BNN Bloomberg, Taylor said the uneven performance of individual companies will bear out in the coming weeks and months. 
 “Many companies continue to fail to hit targets and are at risk of running out of funds. We continue to expect more consolidation and bankruptcies in the sector as the year progresses,” he said. 
 “Long term the prospects remain strong for the winners in this group but governments will be focused on other areas of higher importance for the next while and that may delay the long awaited broader rollout of stores throughout the country and a full rollout of cannabis 2.0 products.” 
 Other thoughts: 
 Karl Berger, senior wealth consultant, Cidel Asset Management: 
 “Historic. No more uncertain than 2008, but a lot of people have forgotten that markets can be really volatile, and in some ways a reminder for equity investors that occasionally bad things happen.”  
 “But out of chaos comes opportunity, and it feels a bit like 2008 in that regard as well. There are many companies that offer fantastic, sustainable dividend yields and that will provide investors with income for the next decade. I guess that’s more about the period going forward than it is about the past, but that’s where I’m looking!” 
 Brian Belski, chief investment strategist, BMO Capital Markets: 
 “A month to forget and a Spring to look forward to. The fastest bear market in history took place in March, an unprecedented period that could result in an unprecedented recovery. After all, bull markets are born from bears.” 
 Brian Madden, senior vice president and portfolio manager, Goodreid Investment Management: 
 “I’d characterize it as the fastest bear market to unfold on record, with widespread damage to the economy and the stock markets, but mitigated somewhat by unprecedented fiscal and monetary stimulus in virtually all developed economies. We think the initial shock and panic phase has subsided, and an interim recovery has taken hold, but we expect aftershocks to reverberate for a few months.”

author: Jeremy Herron and Vildana Hajric
title: U.S. stocks fall, bonds rise with wild quarter wnding
description: U.S. stocks sank, bulging the Dow Jones Industrial Average’s loss in the quarter to a level not seen since 1987 as the pandemic almost certainly plunged the American economy into recession.
content:
U.S. stocks sank, bulging the Dow Jones Industrial Average’s loss in the quarter to a level not seen since 1987 as the pandemic almost certainly plunged the American economy into recession. 
 The blue-chip index tumbled 23 per cent in the three months, closing the period with a 1.9 per cent drop. The S&P 500 fared little better, even after a furious, weeklong 17 per cent rally that halted Tuesday. The Nasdaq 100 Index fell least among major indexes, as dip-buyers targeted the cash-rich tech megacaps that make up its core. 
 There was almost nowhere to hide for Dow investors, as all but one of the 30 members ended lower for the year. Boeing plunged 54 per cent, while Chevron and Exxon sank at least 39 per cent after oil suffered its worst quarterly beatdown on record. Microsoft fared best, ending higher by 0.01 per cent. 
 Risk assets around the world tumbled in the period as governments instituted unprecedented shutdowns in large swaths of the global economy to combat the spread of the deadly coronavirus. Massive government spending and monetary stimulus lifted U.S. stocks from a rout that reached 33 per cent, but the hit to GDP is shaping up to be monumental, with Goldman Sachs now forecasting a 34 per cent contraction in the second quarter before a sharp rebound. 
 As March ends, here are some of the major quartlery moves: 
 
 The record bull market in U.S. stocks turned into a bear market on March 12, 11 years and three days after the last one ended. 
 Bloomberg’s U.S. dollar index surged six per cent, most since 2016, even after tumbling more than three per cent since March 23. 
 The Cboe Volatility Index averaged 57.1 in March, triple the mean in the prior decade. 
 European shares plunged more than 20 per cent for the worst three months since 2002. Spain lost 30 per cent. 
 West Texas oil lost 65 per cent, the worst quarter on record. 
 The 10-year Treasury yield hit 1.94 per cent on Jan. 20. It fell to 0.31 per cent by March 9 and is just over 0.6 per cent now. 
 Gold topped US$1,700 in early March before plunging US$200 an ounce. It’s on track for a sixth quarterly gain. 
 China’s Shanghai Composite lost 10 per cent, while Tokyo’s Topix fell almost 20 per cent in its worst three months since 2008. 
 Copper fell 23 per cent and nickel lost 19 per cent, both most since 2011. 
 The pound fell more than six per cent, while the yen was virtually flat versus the U.S. dollar. 
 South Africa’s rand had its worst quarter since 2001 and Mexico’s peso fell the most since 2008. 
 
 On Tuesday, investors focused on signs that Congress could deliver a fourth round of stimulus as the virus spreads deeper in the country. U.S. President Donald Trump is reportedly seeking a US$2 trillion infrastructure package. Treasuries edged higher, while the U.S. dollar fell and crude pushed back above US$20 a barrel. 
 Investors are at a crossroads, questioning whether extraordinary stimulus by countries and central banks can counter further retrenchment of firms and consumers as the outbreak spreads. 
 New York City, which is emerging as the new epicenter of the pandemic, reported a 16 per cent increase in deaths in six hours. Italy and the Netherlands are considering extending lockdowns, and Spain’s 849 deaths were the most in one day for the country. 
 “The recent market movements do reflect efforts to factor in what has happened on the pandemic control side of things and the stimulus measures,” Cameron Brandt, director of research at EPFR, said by phone. “It’s almost certain that we’ll continue to see volatility.” 
 In Europe, the Stoxx 600 rose and a measure of corporate-credit stress eased. Equities were mixed in Asia, where China had stronger-than-anticipated manufacturing data. The U.S. dollar rose versus the euro. 
 In China, the official purchasing managers’ index rose to 52.0 this month. That’s up from a record low of 35.7 in February and above the 50 mark which signals improving conditions. Still, the country’s bureau of statistics cautioned that the single-month data didn’t necessarily mean that economy has returned to normal level amid continuing coronavirus concerns. 
 These are the main moves in markets: 
 Stocks 
 
 The S&P 500 Index fell 1.7 per cent as of 3:20 p.m. New York time. 
 The Nasdaq 100 Index dropped 0.2 per cent. 
 The Stoxx Europe 600 Index added 1.6 per cent. 
 The MSCI Asia Pacific Index gained 0.4 per cent. 
 
 Currencies 
 
 The Bloomberg U.S. Dollar Spot Index fell 0.1 per cent. 
 The euro declined 0.3 per cent to US$1.1013. 
 The British pound was little changed at US$1.2414. 
 The Japanese yen gained 0.1 per cent to 107.83 per U.S. dollar. 
 
 Bonds 
 
 The yield on 10-year Treasuries declined three basis points to 0.69 per cent. 
 Germany’s 10-year yield climbed by two basis points to -0.46 per cent. 
 
 Commodities 
 
 Gold sank 2.4 per cent to US$1,604.30 an ounce. 
 West Texas Intermediate crude increased 3.1 to US$20.75 a barrel.

 The commodity complex was largely under pressure, with ongoing concerns over global growth in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic and the impact of the oil price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia hammering crude. Benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell more than six percent to its lowest level in nearly two decades, while Alberta’s Western Canadian Select hit a new record low of less than four dollars per barrel. 
 In Toronto, the TSX was led higher by the financials, energy, and industrials subgroups. Energy was the second-largest contributor on a points basis to the composite’s gains, in a move that ran counter to the declines in underlying commodity prices. Suncor Energy Inc. and Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. are two of the dominant members of the index, an aspect a pair of energy investors said should give market watchers pause when it comes to reading too much into the rally. 
 “Canadian best in class, large liquid names caught a bid and now dragging others up,” Rafi Tahmazian, senior portfolio manager at Canoe Financial, said in an email to BNN Bloomberg. “But the results are twisted because two companies represent over 50 [per cent] of the index and they are the 'large liquid flight to quality' names that everybody gravitates to. CNQ and Suncor are up 14 and 17 per cent which makes it look like the whole sector is up.” 
 Ninepoint Partners senior portfolio manager and partner Eric Nuttall took a similar view, telling BNN Bloomberg he expects further divergence between energy companies and oil as markets become more distorted. 
 “Energy stocks are wickedly oversold so we’re due for a bounce,” he said in an email to BNN Bloomberg. “I’ve been expecting them to start to diverge from short-term dynamics as price drops further with ballooning inventories.” 
 Canadian Natural and Suncor capped off the day as two of the three largest percentage movers in the index, along with MEG Energy, whose shares are typically highly volatile to any shift in energy industry trading. On the flip side, cannabis stocks were smacked, with Hexo Corp. posting the largest loss on the composite, followed by Aurora Cannabis Inc. 
 Among the other sharp declines, shares of Cineplex Inc. plunged deeper into the red after JPMorgan analyst Alexander Mees cast serious doubt on the timeline for the company to sell itself to U.K.-based Cineworld Group plc. In a note to clients, Mees said he “cannot envisage a realistic scenario” where the deal could be completed in the first half of this year as the theatre industry grapples with shutdowns due to the virus outbreak. Cineplex reached a deal to sell itself to Cineworld last year for $34 per share. 
 Other losers included Cominar Real Estate Investment Trust, whose units suffered after the company pulled its financial forecast for fiscal 2020 late Friday in the face of the virus. The company, which has office, industrial and retail exposure, said mandated shutdowns of non-essential businesses could hurt its retail unit. It also shelved any planned asset sales in the face of real estate market uncertainty. 
 Inter Pipeline Ltd. shares also fell after the company slashed its dividend 72 per cent, citing the one-two punch of the virus outbreak and the oil price war. The company concurrently cut executive pay and put its plans to sell its European bulk storage business on ice in the face of the uncertainty.

title: 'Don’t be a hero': Market veterans weigh in on managing volatility
description: It’s been a wild week for Canadian investors. Stocks have whipsawed, with the benchmark S&P/TSX Composite Index flirting with bull market territory after plunging 34 per cent from February’s record highs. There’s also been volatility in the bond market as investors seek safe havens and weigh central bank rate cuts designed to cushion the blow from the COVID-19 outbreak.
content:
It’s been a wild week for Canadian investors. Stocks have whipsawed, with the benchmark S&P/TSX Composite Index flirting with bull market territory after plunging 34 per cent from February’s record highs. There’s also been volatility in the bond market as investors seek safe havens and weigh central bank rate cuts designed to cushion the blow from the COVID-19 outbreak. 
 Here’s a look at some recommendations from top investment professionals on what to do, and what not to do, in these volatile times. 
 David Rosenberg, chief economist and strategist, Rosenberg Research & Associates: 
 “There are true bargains out there in areas of the equity market that were the proverbial ‘babies thrown out with the bathwater’ in the recent meltdown that have strong underlying fundamentals and solid recurring cash flow streams.  I am thinking multi-family REITS, utilities and telecom; and each company you buy should be screened for balance sheet strength.  
 “Canada’s recession is going to be even deeper and the recovery shallower, and there are precious few alluring investment themes here at home compared to what you can pick and choose from south of the border. For yield, I would suggest moving out of G7 bond markets and into the emerging market fixed-income universe where the basis-point pickup is considerable. I would definitely avoid any company that is the recipient of bailout money and any company that artificially engineered its earnings via share buybacks in the last bull market.” 
 Mark Wiseman, former Canada Pension Plan Investment Board CEO 
 “These are very difficult times for even the most experienced investors. … It is extremely difficult to time markets. Trying to time these markets is a fool’s errand, you just don’t know where things will go. … It’s hard, and you just to have to take that long-term view. It’s impossible to be an automaton. In the investment horizon most people have, you have to avoid deviating from your principles. A day’s trading, an hour’s trading, it doesn’t matter. You need a long view if you’re an investor, not a trader. Stick to you knitting, don’t panic and try to keep a cool head.” 
 Brian Belski, chief investment strategist, BMO Capital Markets: 
 “I’ve called for a 40-to-50-per-cent rally from the lows. I think the lows are in, though timing remains fluid on when things rebound. 
 “My favourite sector is communications. This is a changing world – people are going to be glued to the couch at home. People are watching Netflix, they’re watching Disney +, they’re watching YouTube. These are opportunities. In terms of the worse thing [investors] can do, they should not be selling now, they should not be getting into fixed income. Bull markets are born of bear markets.” 
 Kurt Reiman, chief investment strategist, Blackrock Canada 
 “In our tactical asset allocation framework, we focus on four equity style factors: momentum, value, quality and minimum volatility. These last two – quality (companies with sound balance sheets) and minimum volatility (companies that have historically exhibited lower volatility) – tend to perform best during periods of either slow economic growth, like the period that prevailed prior to the coronavirus outbreak, or during a contraction in activity like now. We’re overweight both positions in our factor exposure framework.” 
 Barry Schwartz, chief investment officer and portfolio manager, Baskin Wealth Management 
 “If there were good reasons why you bought everything in your portfolio and you can justify that those companies will be here for the long term, then do nothing. I have no doubt that a number of companies won’t ever regain their lofty highs but it is too soon to make that kind of decision. Doing nothing and holding on is the right decision and it is a powerful action. You must tame your animal brain and think rationally. 
 “If you have cash, scale into this market. Don’t be a hero and spend it all in one day. If you are retired or close to retirement, take out a year’s worth of cash flow from your portfolio to tide you over.”

title: 'Through thick and thin': Why stock markets will likely remain open during the COVID-19 pandemic
description: David George-Cosh
content:
David George-Cosh
                             
 Reporter   Follow | Archive 
 
 
 With the COVID-19 pandemic prompting frequent waves of volatility on North American stock markets, some uneasy investors may want this month's rollercoaster ride to end to avoid risking further losses.  
 But halting all stock market activity isn't that easy. The lessons learned from the last financial crisis in 2008 and 2009 ensured that markets will continue to trade, like it or not.  
 "Even in a time of stress, the importance of people having liquidity and with companies being able to access capital, those are critical functions for the marketplace to offer," said John McKenzie, interim chief executive officer and chief financial officer of the TMX Group Ltd, in a phone interview with BNN Bloomberg.  
 The last time U.S. and Canadian stock exchanges shut down was during a four-day period after 9/11 when markets shuttered in anticipation of panic selling and chaos following the terrorist attacks on the U.S. 
 But with fears about how bad the COVID-19 pandemic could get and policymakers around the world enacting extraordinary fiscal and monetary measures to prop economies up, U.S. and Canadian stock markets have frequently hit circuit breakers over the past month, halting trading activity and letting investors take a breather.  
 One Bay Street portfolio manager thinks the COVID-19 pandemic should pause all trading until the virus is properly managed. 
 Patrick Horan, portfolio manager at Toronto-based Agilith Capital Inc., told BNN Bloomberg earlier this month that everyone needs to "collectively stop the economic engine" to eliminate COVID-19 as fast as possible. 
 "The problem is that markets are still open and [investors] are going: 'Who’s going to pay for this?,'" Horan said during a television interview. 
 "It’s going to be one heck of a mess." 
 
 
 
 RELATED  
  Mnuchin wants U.S. markets open, with shorter hours if necessary 
  Damage control: Inside the TSX's 34% slide from record high  
  'Markets are functioning well': TMX CEO calls for trading to continue amid crash 
 
 
 
 That market chatter led the TMX Group to issue a rare response  on its website last week  to let investors know it was in the best interest of publicly-listed companies, investors and other participants for markets to remain open.  
 To help contain investors' frustration amid volatile markets, exchanges established circuit breakers after the 2008 financial crisis. The  benchmark  for the first breaker to be triggered is when an index falls more than seven per cent. 
 That was one of the first takeaways made after that financial crisis to avoid a repeat of the same violent whipsaw of trading activity, according to Susan Wolburgh Jenah, the former president and CEO of the Investment Industry Regulatory Organization of Canada (IIROC) and current board member of the NEO Exchange.  
 "This has always been sacrosanct, but it's better to have the markets working. It's important to have markets remain operational through thick and thin," Jenah told BNN Bloomberg in a phone interview.  
 Shutting down stock exchanges was viewed as "the equivalent of the nuclear bomb in terms of how markets operate," Jenah said. She added there were daily discussions between herself, the Bank of Canada, provincial and federal finance departments and securities regulators to determine the next steps for market activity during the tumultuous 2008 financial crisis.  
 "Is there a single blueprint that gets triggered? Every crisis is different and every set of circumstances will have their own nuances," she said. "There's an apparatus through working with these issues but it involves a lot of conversations and a lot of analysis."
